stem: Which positioning most effectively stretches the rectus femoris muscle?

choices.text: Knee flexion combined with hip extension while maintaining a posterior pelvic tilt
choices.explain: Rectus femoris crosses the hip and knee and performs hip flexion and knee extension; stretching requires hip extension and knee flexion with pelvic control to prevent lumbar substitution.

choices.text: Knee extension with hip flexion
choices.explain: Both movements correspond to the primary actions of rectus femoris and therefore shorten the muscle.

choices.text: Hip flexion with the knee flexed
choices.explain: Hip flexion shortens the muscle proximally, reducing overall lengthening.

choices.text: Knee flexion with anterior pelvic tilt
choices.explain: Anterior pelvic tilt places the rectus femoris in a shortened position at the hip.

stem: Which exercise best strengthens the rectus femoris?

choices.text: Resisted knee extension performed with the hip in slight flexion
choices.explain: Resisted knee extension recruits all quadriceps heads, and slight hip flexion increases rectus femoris contribution due to its biarticular role.

choices.text: Passive knee flexion stretch
choices.explain: Passive stretching does not create a strengthening stimulus.

choices.text: Hip extension with the knee flexed
choices.explain: This movement reduces rectus femoris activation.

choices.text: Isometric hip adduction
choices.explain: Hip adduction does not involve rectus femoris.

stem: Which movement best stretches the vastus lateralis?

choices.text: Passive knee flexion within a pain-free range
choices.explain: Vastus lateralis is a monoarticular knee extensor and is lengthened by knee flexion.

choices.text: Hip extension with knee extended
choices.explain: Vastus lateralis does not cross the hip joint.

choices.text: Terminal knee extension
choices.explain: Terminal knee extension strengthens rather than stretches the muscle.

choices.text: Isometric quadriceps contraction
choices.explain: Isometric contraction does not change muscle length.

stem: Which exercise best strengthens the vastus lateralis?

choices.text: Resisted knee extension through mid-range
choices.explain: Vastus lateralis is a primary knee extensor and is activated during resisted knee extension.

choices.text: Passive knee flexion hold
choices.explain: Passive positioning does not strengthen muscle.

choices.text: Hip abduction against resistance
choices.explain: Hip abduction does not involve vastus lateralis.

choices.text: Ankle dorsiflexion exercises
choices.explain: Ankle dorsiflexion does not recruit quadriceps muscles.

stem: Which movement appropriately stretches the vastus medialis?

choices.text: Passive knee flexion
choices.explain: Vastus medialis is a monoarticular knee extensor and is lengthened during knee flexion.

choices.text: Terminal knee extension
choices.explain: Terminal knee extension strengthens vastus medialis.

choices.text: Hip adduction with knee extended
choices.explain: Vastus medialis does not cross the hip.

choices.text: Isometric quadriceps set
choices.explain: Isometric contraction does not stretch muscle tissue.

stem: Which exercise best emphasizes strengthening of the vastus medialis?

choices.text: Terminal knee extension in standing or supine
choices.explain: Vastus medialis is highly active during terminal knee extension for patellar stabilization.

choices.text: Passive knee flexion stretch
choices.explain: Stretching does not strengthen muscle.

choices.text: Hip external rotation exercise
choices.explain: Hip external rotation does not recruit vastus medialis.

choices.text: Ankle plantarflexion
choices.explain: Plantarflexion recruits calf muscles, not quadriceps.

stem: How is the vastus intermedius best stretched?

choices.text: Passive knee flexion
choices.explain: Vastus intermedius is a monoarticular knee extensor and is lengthened during knee flexion.

choices.text: Hip extension with knee extended
choices.explain: This muscle does not cross the hip.

choices.text: Terminal knee extension
choices.explain: This is a strengthening action.

choices.text: Isometric quadriceps contraction
choices.explain: Isometric contraction does not lengthen muscle.

stem: Which exercise strengthens the vastus intermedius?

choices.text: Resisted knee extension
choices.explain: Vastus intermedius is a primary knee extensor activated during knee extension.

choices.text: Passive knee flexion
choices.explain: Passive movement does not strengthen muscle.

choices.text: Hip flexion exercise
choices.explain: Hip flexion does not involve vastus intermedius.

choices.text: Ankle dorsiflexion
choices.explain: Ankle dorsiflexion does not recruit quadriceps.

stem: Which position best stretches the long head of the biceps femoris?

choices.text: Hip flexion combined with knee extension
choices.explain: The long head performs hip extension and knee flexion; stretching requires hip flexion and knee extension.

choices.text: Hip extension with knee flexion
choices.explain: This matches the muscle’s primary actions.

choices.text: Hip flexion with knee flexed
choices.explain: Knee flexion limits hamstring lengthening.

choices.text: Knee flexion with tibial ER
choices.explain: Knee flexion shortens the biceps femoris.

stem: Which exercise best strengthens the long head of the biceps femoris?

choices.text: Resisted knee flexion with the hip in neutral
choices.explain: The long head contributes strongly to knee flexion, especially when the hip is neutral or extended.

choices.text: Passive hamstring stretch
choices.explain: Stretching does not strengthen muscle.

choices.text: Hip flexion against resistance
choices.explain: Hip flexion is not an action of biceps femoris.

choices.text: Ankle plantarflexion
choices.explain: Plantarflexion recruits calf muscles.

stem: How is the short head of the biceps femoris best stretched?

choices.text: Knee extension
choices.explain: The short head is monoarticular and acts only to flex the knee; knee extension lengthens it.

choices.text: Hip flexion with knee extended
choices.explain: The short head does not cross the hip.

choices.text: Hip extension with knee flexed
choices.explain: This shortens the muscle.

choices.text: Isometric knee flexion
choices.explain: Isometric contraction does not stretch muscle.

stem: Which exercise strengthens the short head of the biceps femoris?

choices.text: Resisted knee flexion
choices.explain: The short head contributes to knee flexion and is strengthened during resisted knee flexion.

choices.text: Hip extension exercise
choices.explain: The short head does not act at the hip.

choices.text: Passive knee extension
choices.explain: Passive movement does not strengthen muscle.

choices.text: Ankle dorsiflexion
choices.explain: Ankle dorsiflexion does not recruit hamstrings.

stem: Which movement best stretches the semitendinosus?

choices.text: Hip flexion with knee extension and slight tibial external rotation
choices.explain: Semitendinosus performs hip extension, knee flexion, and tibial internal rotation; opposite positioning lengthens it.

choices.text: Hip extension with knee flexion
choices.explain: This reproduces the muscle’s primary actions.

choices.text: Knee flexion with tibial internal rotation
choices.explain: This shortens the muscle.

choices.text: Isometric hip adduction
choices.explain: Hip adduction does not stretch semitendinosus.

stem: Which exercise strengthens the semitendinosus?

choices.text: Resisted knee flexion with slight tibial internal rotation
choices.explain: Semitendinosus contributes to knee flexion and tibial internal rotation.

choices.text: Passive hamstring stretch
choices.explain: Stretching does not strengthen muscle.

choices.text: Hip flexion against resistance
choices.explain: Hip flexion is not a hamstring action.

choices.text: Ankle plantarflexion
choices.explain: Plantarflexion does not recruit hamstrings.

stem: Which position best stretches the semimembranosus?

choices.text: Hip flexion with knee extension and tibial external rotation
choices.explain: Semimembranosus performs hip extension, knee flexion, and tibial internal rotation; the opposite positioning stretches it.

choices.text: Hip extension with knee flexion
choices.explain: This shortens the muscle.

choices.text: Knee flexion with tibial internal rotation
choices.explain: This reproduces the muscle’s action.

choices.text: Isometric knee flexion
choices.explain: Isometric contraction does not stretch muscle.

stem: Which exercise best strengthens the semimembranosus?

choices.text: Resisted knee flexion with tibial internal rotation
choices.explain: Semimembranosus assists knee flexion and tibial internal rotation.

choices.text: Passive hamstring stretching
choices.explain: Stretching does not strengthen muscle.

choices.text: Hip flexion exercise
choices.explain: Hip flexion is not an action of semimembranosus.

choices.text: Ankle dorsiflexion
choices.explain: Ankle dorsiflexion does not involve hamstrings.

stem: Which positioning best stretches the sartorius muscle?

choices.text: Hip extension, adduction, and internal rotation with knee extension
choices.explain: Sartorius assists hip flexion, abduction, external rotation, and knee flexion; opposite movements stretch it.

choices.text: Hip flexion and external rotation with knee flexion
choices.explain: This matches the muscle’s primary actions.

choices.text: Hip abduction with knee flexion
choices.explain: This shortens sartorius.

choices.text: Isometric knee flexion
choices.explain: Isometric contraction does not stretch muscle.

stem: Which exercise strengthens the sartorius?

choices.text: Resisted knee flexion combined with tibial internal rotation
choices.explain: Sartorius assists knee flexion and tibial internal rotation.

choices.text: Passive knee extension
choices.explain: Passive movement does not strengthen muscle.

choices.text: Hip adduction against resistance
choices.explain: Hip adduction is not a sartorius action.

choices.text: Ankle plantarflexion
choices.explain: Plantarflexion does not involve sartorius.

stem: Which position best stretches the gracilis muscle?

choices.text: Hip abduction with knee extension
choices.explain: Gracilis performs hip adduction and knee flexion; hip abduction and knee extension stretch it.

choices.text: Hip adduction with knee flexion
choices.explain: This shortens gracilis.

choices.text: Hip flexion with knee flexion
choices.explain: This does not lengthen gracilis.

choices.text: Isometric hip adduction
choices.explain: Isometric contraction does not stretch muscle.

stem: Which exercise strengthens the gracilis?

choices.text: Resisted knee flexion or hip adduction
choices.explain: Gracilis assists knee flexion and hip adduction.

choices.text: Passive hip abduction stretch
choices.explain: Stretching does not strengthen muscle.

choices.text: Hip extension exercise
choices.explain: Hip extension is not an action of gracilis.

choices.text: Ankle dorsiflexion
choices.explain: Ankle dorsiflexion does not involve gracilis.

stem: Which movement best stretches the popliteus muscle?

choices.text: Knee extension with gentle tibial external rotation
choices.explain: Popliteus internally rotates the tibia to unlock the knee; the opposite movement stretches it.

choices.text: Knee flexion with tibial internal rotation
choices.explain: This reproduces popliteus action.

choices.text: Hip flexion with knee extended
choices.explain: Hip position does not affect popliteus length.

choices.text: Isometric knee flexion
choices.explain: Isometric contraction does not stretch muscle.

stem: Which exercise strengthens the popliteus?

choices.text: Resisted tibial internal rotation in slight knee flexion
choices.explain: Popliteus internally rotates the tibia during knee flexion.

choices.text: Passive knee extension stretch
choices.explain: Passive stretching does not strengthen muscle.

choices.text: Hip extension exercise
choices.explain: Hip extension does not involve popliteus.

choices.text: Ankle plantarflexion
choices.explain: Plantarflexion does not involve popliteus.

stem: Which position best stretches the gastrocnemius?

choices.text: Ankle dorsiflexion with the knee extended
choices.explain: Gastrocnemius crosses the knee and ankle; dorsiflexion with knee extension lengthens it maximally.

choices.text: Ankle dorsiflexion with knee flexed
choices.explain: Knee flexion shortens gastrocnemius.

choices.text: Ankle plantarflexion with knee extended
choices.explain: Plantarflexion shortens gastrocnemius.

choices.text: Isometric plantarflexion
choices.explain: Isometric contraction does not stretch muscle.

stem: Which exercise best strengthens the gastrocnemius?

choices.text: Heel raises performed with knees extended
choices.explain: Knee extension biases gastrocnemius during plantarflexion.

choices.text: Heel raises with knees flexed
choices.explain: This emphasizes soleus rather than gastrocnemius.

choices.text: Passive calf stretching
choices.explain: Stretching does not strengthen muscle.

choices.text: Ankle dorsiflexion
choices.explain: Dorsiflexion activates anterior leg muscles.

stem: Which position best stretches the soleus?

choices.text: Ankle dorsiflexion with the knee flexed
choices.explain: Soleus does not cross the knee and is best stretched with knee flexion and ankle dorsiflexion.

choices.text: Ankle dorsiflexion with knee extended
choices.explain: This biases gastrocnemius rather than soleus.

choices.text: Ankle plantarflexion
choices.explain: Plantarflexion shortens soleus.

choices.text: Isometric plantarflexion
choices.explain: Isometric contraction does not stretch muscle.

stem: Which exercise best strengthens the soleus?

choices.text: Heel raises performed with knees flexed
choices.explain: Knee flexion reduces gastrocnemius contribution, emphasizing soleus.

choices.text: Heel raises with knees extended
choices.explain: This emphasizes gastrocnemius.

choices.text: Passive calf stretching
choices.explain: Stretching does not strengthen muscle.

choices.text: Ankle dorsiflexion exercises
choices.explain: Dorsiflexion recruits anterior leg muscles.

stem: Which position best stretches the plantaris muscle?

choices.text: Knee extension combined with ankle dorsiflexion
choices.explain: Plantaris assists knee flexion and plantarflexion; knee extension and dorsiflexion lengthen it.

choices.text: Knee flexion with ankle plantarflexion
choices.explain: This shortens the plantaris.

choices.text: Hip flexion with knee extended
choices.explain: Hip position has minimal effect on plantaris length.

choices.text: Isometric plantarflexion
choices.explain: Isometric contraction does not stretch muscle.

stem: Which exercise strengthens the plantaris?

choices.text: Assisted heel raises
choices.explain: Plantaris assists plantarflexion and is activated during heel raises.

choices.text: Passive ankle dorsiflexion stretch
choices.explain: Stretching does not strengthen muscle.

choices.text: Hip extension exercise
choices.explain: Hip extension does not involve plantaris.

choices.text: Isometric knee extension
choices.explain: Knee extension does not recruit plantaris.

stem: Which method most effectively stretches the frontal belly of the occipitofrontalis?

choices.text: Manually depressing the eyebrow/forehead tissues inferiorly while keeping the brows relaxed (no active eyebrow elevation)
choices.explain: The frontal belly elevates the eyebrows and wrinkles the forehead; a stretch is achieved by keeping the muscle relaxed while passively drawing the brow/forehead tissues downward to lengthen it.

choices.text: Actively raising the eyebrows repeatedly through full range
choices.explain: Active eyebrow elevation is the primary action of the frontal belly and shortens the muscle rather than lengthening it.

choices.text: Clenching the teeth firmly while keeping the mouth closed
choices.explain: Jaw clenching primarily recruits masticatory muscles (e.g., masseter/temporalis) and does not lengthen the frontal belly.

choices.text: Retracting the mandible while maintaining a neutral facial expression
choices.explain: Mandibular retrusion involves jaw musculature and does not create a passive lengthening force across the frontal belly.

stem: Which exercise best targets isometric strengthening of the frontal belly of the occipitofrontalis?

choices.text: Place fingers just above the eyebrows and attempt to raise the eyebrows against the unmoving fingers
choices.explain: The frontal belly elevates the eyebrows; resisting eyebrow elevation without visible movement produces an isometric contraction of the target muscle.

choices.text: Open the jaw as wide as comfortable and hold
choices.explain: Jaw opening primarily involves mandibular depressors and does not directly load eyebrow elevation.

choices.text: Press the tongue firmly into the roof of the mouth
choices.explain: Tongue-palate pressure biases suprahyoid and tongue musculature, not the frontal belly.

choices.text: Perform cervical side-bending against the hand
choices.explain: Cervical side-bending strengthens neck muscles (e.g., SCM/scalenes) rather than the frontal belly.

stem: Which positioning most effectively stretches the temporalis?

choices.text: Gentle mandibular depression (mouth opening), optionally combined with slight contralateral lateral deviation
choices.explain: Temporalis elevates the mandible (and assists retrusion); opening the jaw lengthens it, and contralateral deviation can bias stretch across one side.

choices.text: Maximal jaw clenching with the teeth together
choices.explain: Clenching is strong mandibular elevation, which shortens temporalis and is a strengthening action, not a stretch.

choices.text: Mandibular retrusion with the mouth closed
choices.explain: Retrusion is an action assisted by temporalis; performing it actively does not lengthen the muscle.

choices.text: Cervical flexion with the jaw relaxed
choices.explain: Cervical flexion primarily lengthens posterior cervical extensors and does not reliably lengthen temporalis.

stem: Which exercise best strengthens the temporalis through its primary action?

choices.text: Resisted mandibular elevation: attempt to close the jaw into an unmoving hand/fist placed under the chin (slight opening start)
choices.explain: Temporalis is a primary elevator of the mandible; resisting jaw closing loads the temporalis (and other jaw closers) in a strengthening manner.

choices.text: Passive jaw opening held at end-range
choices.explain: Passive end-range opening lengthens jaw closers and does not provide a strengthening stimulus.

choices.text: Resisted mandibular depression: attempt to open the jaw into resistance
choices.explain: Mandibular depression is the opposite of temporalis' primary role (elevation), so this does not specifically strengthen temporalis.

choices.text: Isometric cervical extension into the hand
choices.explain: Cervical extension strengthens neck extensors rather than the temporalis.

stem: Which position most effectively stretches the masseter?

choices.text: Gentle mandibular depression (mouth opening) within comfort, optionally with very light downward overpressure under the chin
choices.explain: Masseter is a strong mandibular elevator; opening the jaw lengthens the muscle, and light overpressure can increase lengthening if pain-free.

choices.text: Jaw clenching in maximal intercuspation (teeth together)
choices.explain: Clenching is masseter's primary action (elevation) and shortens it; this is strengthening, not stretching.

choices.text: Mandibular protrusion held at end-range
choices.explain: Protrusion is not a lengthening position for masseter overall and does not reliably create a stretch compared with mandibular depression.

choices.text: Cervical rotation to the opposite side
choices.explain: Cervical rotation primarily affects neck musculature and does not directly lengthen the masseter.

stem: Which exercise best strengthens the masseter?

choices.text: Resisted mandibular elevation: attempt to close the jaw into an unmoving fist/hand under the chin (no visible movement)
choices.explain: The masseter is a primary jaw closer; resisting mandibular elevation produces a strengthening contraction of the jaw elevators.

choices.text: Passive mouth opening held for 30 seconds
choices.explain: Passive holding in an open position lengthens jaw closers and does not provide a strengthening load.

choices.text: Resisted jaw opening into the hand
choices.explain: Jaw opening recruits mandibular depressors rather than the masseter, which is an elevator.

choices.text: Isometric tongue press to the palate
choices.explain: Tongue-palate pressure targets tongue and floor-of-mouth control, not the masseter's primary action.

stem: Which movement best stretches the medial pterygoid on the left?

choices.text: Gentle mouth opening combined with mandibular deviation to the left (ipsilateral deviation)
choices.explain: Medial pterygoid assists elevation and contributes to contralateral excursion; positioning the jaw to lengthen a side can be biased by opening plus ipsilateral deviation to place that side under stretch.

choices.text: Jaw clenching with the mandible held midline
choices.explain: Clenching is mandibular elevation, which shortens medial pterygoid rather than lengthening it.

choices.text: Mandibular protrusion against resistance
choices.explain: Protrusion is assisted by medial pterygoid; performing it against resistance is a strengthening action, not a stretch.

choices.text: Cervical side-bending to the right
choices.explain: Cervical side-bending primarily affects neck muscles and does not reliably lengthen medial pterygoid.

stem: Which exercise most directly strengthens the medial pterygoid?

choices.text: Resisted mandibular elevation (jaw closing) with the jaw maintained in midline alignment
choices.explain: Medial pterygoid assists mandibular elevation; resisted jaw closing loads it in a strengthening pattern alongside other elevators.

choices.text: Passive mouth opening held at end-range
choices.explain: Passive opening lengthens jaw elevators and does not provide strengthening stimulus.

choices.text: Resisted cervical flexion into the hand
choices.explain: Cervical flexion strengthens anterior neck musculature, not mandibular elevators.

choices.text: Resisted jaw opening into the hand
choices.explain: Jaw opening recruits mandibular depressors; medial pterygoid is primarily an elevator.

stem: Which positioning most effectively lengthens (stretches) the lateral pterygoid?

choices.text: Mandibular retrusion back toward neutral (from a slightly protruded position) while keeping the jaw relaxed
choices.explain: Lateral pterygoid contributes to mandibular protrusion and assists opening; moving from protrusion back toward retrusion/neutral places it in a lengthened position.

choices.text: Active mandibular protrusion held at end-range
choices.explain: Protrusion is a primary action of lateral pterygoid and shortens it, making this a strengthening/activation position rather than a stretch.

choices.text: Jaw clenching with teeth together
choices.explain: Clenching primarily involves jaw elevators and does not lengthen the lateral pterygoid.

choices.text: Cervical extension with the mouth closed
choices.explain: Cervical extension changes neck posture but does not reliably lengthen the lateral pterygoid.

stem: Which exercise best targets strengthening of the lateral pterygoid?

choices.text: Resisted mandibular protrusion: push the jaw forward against gentle resistance applied to the chin
choices.explain: Lateral pterygoid contributes strongly to mandibular protrusion; applying resistance to forward glide loads the muscle for strengthening.

choices.text: Passive mouth opening held for 30 seconds
choices.explain: Passive holding does not provide a strengthening stimulus and primarily lengthens jaw elevators.

choices.text: Resisted jaw closing into the hand
choices.explain: Jaw closing targets mandibular elevators; lateral pterygoid is primarily associated with protrusion (and assisting opening), not elevation.

choices.text: Isometric cervical rotation into the hand
choices.explain: Cervical rotation strengthens neck rotators and does not specifically strengthen the lateral pterygoid.

stem: Which positioning most effectively stretches the right sternocleidomastoid (SCM)?

choices.text: Left side-bending combined with right rotation and slight cervical extension (pain-free)
choices.explain: Right SCM contributes to ipsilateral side-bending and contralateral rotation; placing the neck into contralateral side-bending with ipsilateral rotation and extension lengthens the SCM.

choices.text: Right side-bending with left rotation
choices.explain: This matches right SCM's unilateral action pattern (ipsilateral side-bend with contralateral rotation) and therefore shortens it.

choices.text: Chin tuck with gentle cervical flexion
choices.explain: Chin tuck biases deep cervical flexors and does not selectively lengthen the SCM compared with contralateral side-bending and ipsilateral rotation.

choices.text: Cervical extension with head rotated left
choices.explain: Left rotation is contralateral rotation for the right SCM and tends to recruit/shorten it rather than lengthen it when combined with extension.

stem: Which exercise best strengthens the sternocleidomastoid through cervical flexion?

choices.text: Isometric cervical flexion: press the forehead into the hand without visible movement
choices.explain: Bilateral SCM contributes to cervical flexion; resisting flexion isometrically loads the SCM (and other flexors) for strengthening.

choices.text: Passive cervical extension stretch held for 30 seconds
choices.explain: Passive extension is a stretching position for anterior neck muscles and does not create a strengthening contraction.

choices.text: Cervical side-bending away from the hand without resistance
choices.explain: Unresisted movement does not provide an adequate strengthening load and does not specifically target SCM's role in flexion.

choices.text: Scapular depression holds with the neck relaxed
choices.explain: Scapular depression targets shoulder girdle depressors and does not strengthen SCM.

stem: Which technique best stretches the right scalenes while minimizing substitution?

choices.text: Left side-bending with slight cervical extension while stabilizing the right first rib/clavicular area (pain-free)
choices.explain: Scalenes side-bend the neck ipsilaterally and elevate the upper ribs; contralateral side-bending with rib stabilization lengthens the scalenes more effectively.

choices.text: Right side-bending with deep inhalation
choices.explain: Right side-bending shortens the right scalenes, and deep inhalation recruits them as accessory inspiratory muscles rather than stretching them.

choices.text: Cervical flexion with chin tuck only
choices.explain: Chin tuck primarily biases deep cervical flexors; it does not specifically lengthen the scalenes as effectively as contralateral side-bending with rib stabilization.

choices.text: Shoulder shrugs with the neck neutral
choices.explain: Shoulder shrugs target scapular elevators and do not place a lengthening bias on the scalenes.

stem: Which exercise best strengthens the scalenes as cervical lateral flexors?

choices.text: Isometric cervical side-bending into the hand (no visible movement), performed on each side
choices.explain: Scalenes contribute to ipsilateral side-bending and stabilization; resisting side-bending isometrically loads them appropriately for strengthening.

choices.text: Passive cervical side-bending stretch held for 30 seconds
choices.explain: Passive stretching lengthens tissue but does not produce a strengthening contraction.

choices.text: Resisted shoulder abduction with the neck relaxed
choices.explain: Shoulder abduction targets deltoid and scapular rotators; it does not strengthen the scalenes' cervical action.

choices.text: Jaw clenching against resistance
choices.explain: Jaw clenching strengthens masticatory muscles and does not strengthen cervical lateral flexors.

stem: Which position best stretches the platysma?

choices.text: Gentle cervical extension with the jaw relaxed and lips soft (no forceful end-range)
choices.explain: Platysma spans the superficial anterior neck and assists mandibular depression and lower lip depression; lengthening is biased by extending the cervical region with relaxed facial tension.

choices.text: Forceful jaw opening with the chin tucked
choices.explain: Forceful jaw opening emphasizes mandibular depressors, and chin tuck does not lengthen the superficial anterior neck tissues as reliably as gentle extension.

choices.text: Cervical flexion with shoulders elevated
choices.explain: Cervical flexion shortens anterior neck tissues and does not place platysma in a lengthened position.

choices.text: Jaw clenching with teeth together
choices.explain: Clenching recruits jaw elevators and does not lengthen platysma.

stem: Which exercise best targets strengthening of the platysma?

choices.text: Actively depress the lower lip and corners of the mouth to tense the anterior neck (controlled, pain-free)
choices.explain: Platysma draws the lower lip/corners downward and tenses the skin of the anterior neck; performing this action actively loads the muscle for strengthening.

choices.text: Resisted cervical extension into the hand
choices.explain: Cervical extension strengthens posterior neck extensors, not the superficial platysma.

choices.text: Resisted jaw closing into a fist
choices.explain: Jaw closing strengthens mandibular elevators (masseter/temporalis) rather than platysma.

choices.text: Passive cervical extension stretch held for 30 seconds
choices.explain: Passive holding is stretching and does not produce a strengthening contraction.

stem: Which movement most directly lengthens (stretches) the longus colli?

choices.text: Gentle cervical extension performed within a comfortable mid-range (no end-range jamming)
choices.explain: Longus colli is a deep cervical flexor and stabilizer; controlled cervical extension lengthens deep cervical flexors.

choices.text: Chin tuck held isometrically in supine
choices.explain: A chin tuck is a primary activation/strengthening strategy for deep cervical flexors and does not lengthen them.

choices.text: Cervical flexion with the chin moving toward the chest
choices.explain: Cervical flexion shortens the deep cervical flexors rather than lengthening them.

choices.text: Shoulder shrugging with the head neutral
choices.explain: Shrugging targets scapular elevators and does not lengthen deep cervical flexors.

stem: Which exercise best isolates strengthening of the deep cervical flexors (including longus colli)?

choices.text: Supine chin tuck (cranio-cervical flexion) without lifting the head from the surface
choices.explain: A controlled chin tuck targets deep cervical flexors by minimizing superficial compensations and focusing on segmental control.

choices.text: Full sit-up with hands behind the head
choices.explain: A sit-up heavily biases trunk flexors and often recruits superficial neck flexors; it does not isolate deep cervical flexors.

choices.text: Cervical extension against the hand
choices.explain: Extension strengthens posterior neck extensors, which oppose longus colli's primary flexor role.

choices.text: Jaw clenching against resistance
choices.explain: Clenching recruits masticatory muscles and does not strengthen deep cervical flexors.

stem: Which movement most directly stretches the longus capitis?

choices.text: Gentle upper-cervical extension (chin slightly up) performed within comfort
choices.explain: Longus capitis contributes to cervical flexion (especially upper cervical control); gentle extension lengthens it.

choices.text: Upper-cervical flexion (chin nod) held isometrically
choices.explain: A chin nod is a primary activation pattern for deep cervical flexors and would shorten rather than lengthen longus capitis.

choices.text: Cervical flexion with chin-to-chest motion
choices.explain: Flexion shortens the deep cervical flexors rather than stretching them.

choices.text: Scapular retraction holds
choices.explain: Scapular retraction targets shoulder girdle musculature and does not lengthen longus capitis.

stem: Which exercise best strengthens longus capitis as a deep cervical flexor?

choices.text: Supine chin nod (cranio-cervical flexion) with minimal superficial neck activity
choices.explain: A chin nod emphasizes upper cervical flexor control, recruiting deep flexors such as longus capitis with reduced compensation.

choices.text: Resisted cervical extension into the hand
choices.explain: Extension strengthens posterior extensors, which oppose longus capitis' flexor function.

choices.text: Passive cervical extension stretch held 30 seconds
choices.explain: Passive stretching does not provide a strengthening contraction.

choices.text: Jaw opening against resistance
choices.explain: Resisted jaw opening targets mandibular depressors and does not strengthen deep cervical flexors.

stem: Which positioning most effectively stretches the right upper trapezius?

choices.text: Left cervical side-bending with the right shoulder gently depressed (pain-free)
choices.explain: Upper trapezius elevates the scapula and contributes to ipsilateral side-bending; contralateral side-bending combined with scapular depression lengthens it.

choices.text: Right cervical side-bending with right shoulder elevation
choices.explain: Ipsilateral side-bending and shoulder elevation replicate upper trapezius actions and shorten the muscle.

choices.text: Cervical extension with shoulder shrugging
choices.explain: Extension and shrugging recruit and shorten the upper trapezius rather than lengthening it.

choices.text: Cervical rotation to the left with both shoulders relaxed, without side-bending
choices.explain: Rotation alone does not reliably lengthen upper trapezius as effectively as contralateral side-bending with scapular depression.

stem: Which exercise best strengthens the upper trapezius through scapular elevation?

choices.text: Controlled shoulder shrugs against resistance (e.g., dumbbells or band), elevating the scapulae
choices.explain: Upper trapezius is a primary scapular elevator; resisted scapular elevation is a direct strengthening action.

choices.text: Passive upper trapezius stretch held for 30 seconds
choices.explain: Passive stretching lengthens tissues but does not provide a strengthening contraction.

choices.text: Resisted scapular depression (pushing shoulders down) against a strap
choices.explain: Scapular depression strengthens scapular depressors and opposes upper trapezius' elevation role.

choices.text: Jaw clenching into resistance
choices.explain: Jaw clenching strengthens masticatory muscles, not upper trapezius.

stem: Which positioning best stretches the right levator scapulae?

choices.text: Cervical flexion with rotation to the left and slight left side-bending while depressing the right scapula
choices.explain: Levator scapulae elevates and downwardly rotates the scapula and contributes to ipsilateral cervical rotation/side-bending; flexion with contralateral rotation/side-bending plus scapular depression lengthens it.

choices.text: Cervical extension with rotation to the right
choices.explain: Extension and ipsilateral rotation bias levator scapulae activation and shorten the muscle.

choices.text: Right shoulder shrugging with the neck neutral
choices.explain: Shrugging is scapular elevation, a primary levator scapulae action, and therefore shortens it.

choices.text: Cervical rotation to the right with the right shoulder elevated
choices.explain: Ipsilateral rotation and scapular elevation replicate levator scapulae functions and do not produce a stretch.

stem: Which exercise best strengthens the levator scapulae?

choices.text: Resisted scapular elevation on the involved side (e.g., unilateral shrug against resistance)
choices.explain: Levator scapulae is a scapular elevator; resisted elevation (shrugging) strengthens it.

choices.text: Passive levator scapulae stretch held for 30 seconds
choices.explain: Passive stretching does not produce a strengthening contraction.

choices.text: Resisted scapular upward rotation (e.g., overhead press emphasis)
choices.explain: Upward rotation is primarily produced by upper/lower trapezius and serratus anterior, not levator scapulae (a downward rotator).

choices.text: Resisted jaw opening into the hand
choices.explain: Jaw opening targets mandibular depressors and does not strengthen levator scapulae.

stem: Which positioning most effectively stretches the right splenius capitis?

choices.text: Cervical flexion combined with left rotation and slight left side-bending
choices.explain: Splenius capitis extends the neck and rotates/side-bends ipsilaterally; flexion with contralateral rotation/side-bending lengthens it.

choices.text: Cervical extension with right rotation
choices.explain: Extension and ipsilateral rotation are primary actions of the splenius capitis and shorten it.

choices.text: Chin nod (upper cervical flexion) only
choices.explain: A chin nod primarily targets upper cervical segments and is more specific to suboccipital control than lengthening splenius capitis.

choices.text: Right side-bending with neutral rotation
choices.explain: Ipsilateral side-bending shortens the right splenius capitis rather than stretching it.

stem: Which exercise best strengthens the splenius capitis through its unilateral action?

choices.text: Isometric cervical extension with ipsilateral rotation into an unmoving hand placed on the back-lateral head
choices.explain: Splenius capitis produces cervical extension and ipsilateral rotation; resisting this combined action loads the muscle for strengthening.

choices.text: Passive cervical flexion stretch held for 30 seconds
choices.explain: Passive stretching lengthens posterior tissues and does not provide strengthening stimulus.

choices.text: Isometric cervical flexion into the hand
choices.explain: Cervical flexion strengthens anterior neck flexors and opposes splenius capitis' extensor role.

choices.text: Jaw clenching against resistance
choices.explain: Jaw clenching strengthens masticatory muscles and does not strengthen splenius capitis.

stem: Which position best stretches the left splenius cervicis?

choices.text: Cervical flexion with right rotation and slight right side-bending
choices.explain: Splenius cervicis extends and rotates/side-bends ipsilaterally; flexion with contralateral rotation/side-bending lengthens it.

choices.text: Cervical extension with left rotation
choices.explain: Extension and ipsilateral rotation replicate splenius cervicis actions and shorten it.

choices.text: Left side-bending with neutral rotation
choices.explain: Ipsilateral side-bending shortens the left splenius cervicis rather than stretching it.

choices.text: Upper-cervical chin nod only
choices.explain: A chin nod primarily biases upper cervical flexion and is not the most effective global stretch for splenius cervicis.

stem: Which exercise best strengthens the splenius cervicis?

choices.text: Isometric cervical extension into the hand with an added ipsilateral rotation intent (no visible motion)
choices.explain: Splenius cervicis contributes to extension and ipsilateral rotation; resisting these actions loads it for strengthening.

choices.text: Passive cervical flexion stretch held 30 seconds
choices.explain: Passive holding is stretching and does not strengthen posterior cervical muscles.

choices.text: Isometric cervical flexion into the hand
choices.explain: Flexion strengthens anterior neck muscles and opposes splenius cervicis' extensor function.

choices.text: Resisted shoulder abduction with the head neutral
choices.explain: Shoulder abduction targets glenohumeral musculature and does not strengthen splenius cervicis.

stem: Which movement best stretches the suboccipital muscles?

choices.text: Gentle upper-cervical flexion (small chin nod as if saying \"yes\" slightly), without mid-lower cervical flexion
choices.explain: Suboccipitals primarily produce fine upper-cervical extension; a controlled chin nod places the upper cervical spine into flexion, lengthening them.

choices.text: Full cervical extension (looking up) to end-range
choices.explain: Extension shortens suboccipitals and is the opposite of a stretch for these muscles.

choices.text: Cervical side-bending to end-range
choices.explain: Side-bending does not specifically bias suboccipital lengthening as effectively as upper-cervical flexion.

choices.text: Jaw opening held at end-range
choices.explain: Jaw opening targets mandibular mechanics and does not directly lengthen suboccipital muscles.

stem: Which exercise best targets isometric strengthening of the suboccipitals without excessive lower-cervical substitution?

choices.text: Apply light resistance at the occiput and perform a tiny upper-cervical extension effort without gross neck movement
choices.explain: Suboccipitals control fine upper-cervical extension; a small isometric extension effort against light resistance targets them while minimizing global cervical extensor dominance.

choices.text: Resisted cervical flexion into the hand
choices.explain: Cervical flexion strengthens anterior neck flexors, not suboccipital extensors.

choices.text: Full-range cervical extension repetitions against resistance
choices.explain: Large-range extension heavily recruits global cervical extensors and does not specifically isolate suboccipital control.

choices.text: Passive chin nod stretch held 30 seconds
choices.explain: Passive stretching does not produce a strengthening contraction.

stem: Which movement best stretches the rectus capitis posterior major?

choices.text: Gentle upper-cervical flexion (small chin nod), keeping the mid-lower cervical spine relatively neutral
choices.explain: Rectus capitis posterior major is an upper-cervical extensor and rotator; upper-cervical flexion lengthens it most directly.

choices.text: Upper-cervical extension (looking slightly up)
choices.explain: Extension is the primary action of rectus capitis posterior major and shortens it.

choices.text: Cervical flexion to chin-on-chest with thoracic flexion
choices.explain: Global flexion may lengthen posterior tissues broadly but is less specific to the upper-cervical segmental target than a controlled chin nod.

choices.text: Mandibular protrusion held at end-range
choices.explain: Mandibular protrusion is a jaw movement and does not directly lengthen this upper-cervical muscle.

stem: Which exercise best strengthens the rectus capitis posterior major in a controlled manner?

choices.text: Isometric tiny upper-cervical extension into light resistance applied at the occiput
choices.explain: This muscle contributes to upper-cervical extension; a small isometric extension effort targets it while limiting global extensor substitution.

choices.text: Isometric chin tuck (upper-cervical flexion) against resistance
choices.explain: A chin tuck is upper-cervical flexion and would oppose and lengthen posterior upper-cervical extensors rather than strengthen them.

choices.text: Passive upper-cervical flexion stretch held 30 seconds
choices.explain: Passive stretching does not create a strengthening contraction.

choices.text: Resisted jaw closing into the hand
choices.explain: Jaw closing strengthens mandibular elevators and does not strengthen upper-cervical extensors.

stem: Which movement best stretches the rectus capitis posterior minor?

choices.text: Gentle upper-cervical flexion (small chin nod) performed slowly and within comfort
choices.explain: Rectus capitis posterior minor is a small upper-cervical extensor; upper-cervical flexion lengthens it.

choices.text: Upper-cervical extension with the chin lifted
choices.explain: Extension is the muscle's primary action and therefore shortens it.

choices.text: Cervical side-bending to end-range
choices.explain: Side-bending is not the primary lengthening direction for this upper-cervical extensor.

choices.text: Mandibular depression (mouth opening) held
choices.explain: Jaw opening is not a cervical segmental stretch for rectus capitis posterior minor.

stem: Which exercise best strengthens the rectus capitis posterior minor while minimizing global neck extensor dominance?

choices.text: Isometric tiny upper-cervical extension into light occipital resistance (no visible motion)
choices.explain: This muscle contributes to fine upper-cervical extension; a small isometric effort best targets the intended segmental action.

choices.text: Resisted cervical flexion into the hand
choices.explain: Cervical flexion strengthens anterior flexors and does not strengthen posterior upper-cervical extensors.

choices.text: Passive chin nod stretch held 30 seconds
choices.explain: Passive stretching does not provide a strengthening contraction.

choices.text: Full-range resisted cervical extension repetitions
choices.explain: Large-range extension predominantly trains global extensors rather than targeting fine upper-cervical control.

stem: Which movement best stretches the obliquus capitis superior?

choices.text: Gentle upper-cervical flexion (chin nod) performed slowly and within comfort
choices.explain: Obliquus capitis superior contributes to upper-cervical extension and stabilization; upper-cervical flexion lengthens it.

choices.text: Upper-cervical extension (chin up) held
choices.explain: Extension shortens this upper-cervical extensor rather than stretching it.

choices.text: Mandibular retrusion held
choices.explain: Mandibular retrusion is a jaw movement and does not lengthen an upper-cervical muscle.

choices.text: Thoracic extension over a chair back
choices.explain: Thoracic extension affects thoracic spine mechanics and does not specifically lengthen upper-cervical suboccipital muscles.

stem: Which exercise most directly strengthens the obliquus capitis superior?

choices.text: Isometric tiny upper-cervical extension effort into light resistance at the occiput
choices.explain: Obliquus capitis superior contributes to upper-cervical extension; a small isometric extension effort loads it appropriately.

choices.text: Isometric chin tuck into resistance
choices.explain: A chin tuck is upper-cervical flexion and would oppose and lengthen the obliquus capitis superior rather than strengthen it.

choices.text: Passive upper-cervical flexion stretch held 30 seconds
choices.explain: Passive stretching does not provide strengthening stimulus.

choices.text: Resisted jaw closing into a fist
choices.explain: Jaw closing targets mandibular elevators, not upper-cervical musculature.

stem: Which positioning best stretches the right obliquus capitis inferior?

choices.text: Upper-cervical flexion (chin nod) combined with gentle left rotation (pain-free)
choices.explain: Obliquus capitis inferior contributes to ipsilateral rotation and upper-cervical extension; placing the upper cervical spine into flexion and rotating contralaterally (left rotation for the right side) lengthens the muscle.

choices.text: Upper-cervical extension (chin slightly up) combined with right rotation
choices.explain: Extension and ipsilateral rotation match the muscle's primary actions and therefore shorten the right obliquus capitis inferior.

choices.text: Cervical flexion to chin-on-chest without controlling upper-cervical motion
choices.explain: Global cervical flexion without segmental control does not specifically bias upper-cervical rotation/flexion needed to lengthen the obliquus capitis inferior.

choices.text: Mandibular protrusion held at end-range
choices.explain: Mandibular protrusion is a jaw motion and does not directly lengthen an upper-cervical rotator such as the obliquus capitis inferior.
